entry.title: 6 hydration myths that could be hurting your health
entry.summary:
You donâ€™t have to feel thirsty to be dehydrated. Experts say common myths about hydration can keep people from getting the fluids they need. Think you need 8 cups of water a day? Or that coffee dehydrates you? Experts debunk the most common misconceptions about staying hydrated.
Even though water is the most abundant substance in the human body, it doesnâ€™t always get the respect it deserves. Nearly half of adults in the U.S. consume less than the recommended amount of water per day, according to a 2023 CivicScience poll of nearly 2,861 people. Thatâ€™s a problemâ€”because staying well hydrated is one of the simplest and most powerful ways to support your health.
For starters, itâ€™s essential for body temperature regulation, joint lubrication, digestion, detoxification, nutrient traâ€¦

entry.title: Where to travel in August
entry.summary:
August is dry season in Ecuador, making for great jungle hikes and wildlife watching opportunities. Expectations and temperatures run high in August. From far-flung Ecuadorian escapes to island-hopping in Scotland, here are some of the destinations worthy of your attention this summer.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Travel in August is all about being canny. Itâ€™s a prime time to be in Europe but you need to be nimble to avoid the crowds and escalating prices across the Med and beaches radiating beyond. It's worth thinking of alternatives if you want more than a packed fly-and-flop beach break or an overheated European city visit where half the venues are closed for the summer.
August is a great time for families to head to far flung desâ€¦

entry.title: General Assembly approves $5.4 billion UN peacekeeping budget for 2025-2026
entry.summary: The General Assembly on Monday approved a $5.38 billion budget for UN peacekeeping operations for the 2025-2026 fiscal year, down slightly from the previous year, as delegates wrapped up weeks of negotiations amid warnings about persistent funding challenges.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Families deprived of the means for survival, humanitarians warn
entry.summary: The United Nations on Tuesday reported that humanitarian operations in Gaza are facing escalating strain, as ongoing fuel shortages, access restrictions and military activity continue to undermine aid delivery and essential services.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan: UN warns of soaring displacement and looming floods
entry.summary: UN humanitarians on Tuesday sounded the alarm over worsening humanitarian conditions in Sudan, as escalating violence continues to displace civilians and the rising risk of severe flooding during the current rainy season.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Iran crisis: UN stays and delivers
entry.summary: A clearer picture of needs across Iran is beginning to emerge after the conflict this month with Israel, which left hundreds dead, several hospitals hit and a spike in Afghan refugees returning home, the UNâ€™s top official in Tehran said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Childrenâ€™s lives â€˜turned upside downâ€™ by wars across Middle East, North Africa, warns UNICEF
entry.summary: Conflicts in the Middle East and North Africa in the last two years reportedly killed, maimed, or displaced over 12 million children across the region, according to the UN Childrenâ€™s Fund (UNICEF).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜The margins of the budgetâ€™: Gender equality in developing countries underfunded by $420 billion annually
entry.summary: Developing countries currently face a staggering $420 billion annual gap in the funding needed to achieve gender equality, UN Women estimates. This gap means that programmes and services for women and girls are chronically underfunded.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: 50 years of CITES: Shielding wildlife from trade-driven extinction
entry.summary: The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) marks 50 years since it entered into force on Tuesday, celebrating five decades of protecting endangered wildlife from overexploitation through international trade.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Spain and Brazil push global action to tax the super-rich and curb inequality
entry.summary: Spain and Brazil have launched a joint initiative to promote a higher tax take from the super-rich worldwide, aiming to tackle soaring inequality by ensuring those with the most, pay their fair share.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Northern hemisphere heatwave underscores value of early-warning alerts
entry.summary: The blistering early-summer heatwave thatâ€™s brought life-threatening temperatures across much of the northern hemisphere is a worrying sign of things to come, UN weather experts said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Eating disorders are on the rise in menopausal women
entry.summary:
Experts say that eating disorders are more common during menopause than you might thinkâ€”a result of hormonal changes as well as an array of societal pressures and unique midlife challenges. Long overlooked in women 40 and older, midlife eating disorders are going up. Eating disorder specialists cite hormonal shifts, societal pressures, and past struggles as fueling the silent surge.
Eating disorders are quietly but steadily increasing among women in midlife and beyond.Â
Doctors and specialists say theyâ€™ve seen a noticeable uptick in women ages 40 to 70 seeking help for disordered eating. And because these women donâ€™t fit the stereotype of a person with an eating disorderâ€”namely, theyâ€™re not teenage girlsâ€”they often experience missed diagnoses or delayed care.
â€œNothing is â€¦

entry.title: Why Noahâ€™s Ark will never be found
entry.summary:
A painting of Noahâ€™s Ark. The Old Testament tale has not only inspired countless generations of artists, but also more than a century of â€œscientificâ€ attempts to locate remains of the fabled vessel. For more than a century, people have sought the precise location of Noahâ€™s Ark. Archaeologists say itâ€™s a foolâ€™s errand.
Noahâ€™s Ark is among the best known and most captivating of all Old Testament stories. After creating humans, GodÂ became so displeased with themÂ that he struck Earth with an all-encompassing flood to wipe them out.
But there was one noteworthy (and seaworthy) exception: the biblical patriarch and his family. Accompanied by pairs of each of the planetâ€™s animals, all rode out the deluge in an enormous wooden vessel.
For people who accept the religious text as aâ€¦

entry.title: U.S. or Britishâ€”which set of Virgin Islands is right for you?
entry.summary:
The USVI and BVI are home to world-famous beaches, water sports, and the freshest seafood. Much like the United States and Britain, the USVI and BVI are similar but different in the most nuanced ways. Here are some tips for the traveler trying to determine where to land.
Boasting a sailing culture like no other, the Virgin Islands archipelago calls to travelers from all over the globe. Blue-green waves as clear as glass shimmer and dance, revealing a sprawling underwater ecosystem that weaves its way through caves, tunnels, shipwrecks, and reefs. Britain maintains governance over the eastern isles while the United States is responsible forÂ the west.
This split presents the modern traveler with a dilemma: USVI or BVI?Â Read on to learn more about each, and discover which set of â€¦

entry.title: The legend of Area 51â€”and why it still fascinates us
entry.summary:
The myths surrounding Area 51 draw tourists from around the world, as people travel to the air base near Rachel, Nevada, in hopes to catch a glimpse of otherworldly spacecrafts.Â
Although the legend of extraterrestrials at the top-secret facility has been discredited for years, some of the myths are based on true events. Hereâ€™s what you need to know about Area 51.Â
Area 51 is one of the most famous military installations in the worldâ€”a remarkable feat considering the government didnâ€™t formally acknowledge the site existed until 2013. Rumors of hidden extraterrestrial technology and lifeforms have fueled its popularity and the publicâ€™s imagination for decades.
While no proof of aliens has yet surfaced, declassified information reveals that during the Cold War, the CIA and Aâ€¦

entry.title: Your next adventure: Unwind in Hakone, just outside Tokyo
entry.summary:
Tokyoâ€™s vibrant metropolis is a must-visit on any trip to Japanâ€”but just a short journey away is the town of Hakone, a serene escape where natural hot springs, mountain views, and tradition peacefully await. â€œTokyo is really the center of everything,â€ says National Geographic photographer Jonathan Irish. â€œBut Hakone is the opposite of that. Itâ€™s where people in Tokyo go to relax and recharge.â€
Southwest of Tokyo and nestled in Kanagawa Prefectureâ€”a regional jurisdiction somewhat similar to a state or provinceâ€”Hakone offers a serene escape from city life. Known for its rejuvenating onsens (natural hot springs), historic teahouses, and breathtaking views of Mount Fuji, it has long been a favorite day-trip retreat for those seeking the traditional wellness remedies of the region. And, luâ€¦

entry.title: Gaza: UN urges Israel to allow fuel into Strip
entry.summary: The crisis in Gaza is worsening, UN humanitarians warned on Monday, as ongoing hostilities and access restrictions drive displaced communities deeper into despair.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: â€˜Unbearableâ€™ suffering continues, UN official tells Security Council
entry.summary: The humanitarian crisis in Gaza is deepening at an alarming rate, a senior United Nations official warned on Monday, as Israeli military operations and attacks on civilians seeking aid continue to exact a devastating toll on lives and infrastructure.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Report reveals significant rise in civilian casualties and rights violations in Ukraine
entry.summary: Civilian casualties and violations in Ukraine have significantly escalated in recent months, including a sharp rise in often deadly drone attacks, the UN human rights office, OHCHR, said in a report published on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Afghanistan: Surging returns from Iran overwhelm fragile support systems, UN agencies warn
entry.summary: More than 700,000 Afghan migrants have returned from Iran so far this year, including 256,000 in June alone, the UN International Organization for Migration (IOM) reported on Monday, warning of immense pressures on Afghanistanâ€™s overstretched support systems.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Human rights can be a â€˜strong lever for progressâ€™ in climate change, says UN rights chief
entry.summary: The UNâ€™s top rights official on Monday urged the international community to confront the growing human rights implications of climate change.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Every hour, 100 people die of loneliness-related causes, UN health agency reports
entry.summary: One in six people are affected by loneliness, with significant implications for health and well-being, according to a new report from the UN World Health Organization (WHO).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: After the big development pledges in Sevilla, UN says action starts now
entry.summary: Now the big promises have been formally adopted in the Spanish city of Seville to turbocharge financing for sustainable development, how are the ambitious goals going to be met â€“ and how quickly?

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Itâ€™s time to finance our future and â€˜change courseâ€™, Guterres tells world leaders in Sevilla
entry.summary: â€œWeâ€™re here in Sevilla to change course,â€ the UN chief told world leaders on Monday, calling on them to grasp a once-in-a-decade opportunity to close a $4 trillion financing gap facing developing countries to meet sustainable development goals â€“ and build a better world for all.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Funding shortages threaten relief for millions of Sudanese refugees: WFP
entry.summary: Critical shortfalls in global humanitarian funding now threaten millions of Sudanese refugees fleeing war to seek refuge in neighbouring countries, the UN World Food Programme (WFP) said on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: This is the story behind the Great Compromise
entry.summary:
Tempers were fraying in the muggy chambers of Pennsylvaniaâ€™s statehouse. Excluding Rhode Island, delegates from 12 states had been meeting in Philadelphia for seven weeks to reshape the young countryâ€™s Articles of Confederation into a new, more functional national constitution. The convention included some of the nationâ€™s most respected leaders, including Gen. George Washington, 81-year-old Benjamin Franklin, Virginia legislator James Madison, and the young firebrand Alexander Hamilton. Many had served in the Continental Army; all were male, white, and prosperous landowners. Yet by July they were deadlocked over a key issue: how to allot power in the newly formed United States.
(He was a Founding Father. His son sided with the British.)
The argument came down to big states versusâ€¦

entry.title: This is what a meal looks like in Canada's Niagara wine country
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
â€œIâ€™m not really a farmer,â€ Renee Delaney tells me sheepishly, despite our surroundings clearly suggesting otherwise.
Nearby, a chorus of grunting piglets wallow in a mud bath, overlooked by a pen of miniature goats. â€œAll this started life 10 years ago with just one tomato plant, which I brought to put food on the table as a single mother,â€ says Renee. She gestures, with an arm covered in botanical tattoos, at her 19-acre plot at Small Scale Farms. An abundant tapestry of potato fields and vines bowing under the weight of juicy ripe tomatoes unfurls towards a distant red barn, which is home to the farm shop, painting a glorious picture of rural idyll.
Canadaâ€™s Niagara Region, in the province of Ontario, encompaâ€¦

entry.title: Investigating Cold Cases: How Two Journalists Dug Into Decades-Old Civil Rights Era Killings
entry.summary: To resurrect civil rights era cold cases, two reporters uncovered new sources and accessed forgotten government documents to reconsider the historical record.

entry.title: Register for Free Training Course: Digital Security for Journalists in Times of Crisis
entry.summary: The Global Investigative Journalism Network and the Knight Center for Journalism in the Americas are offering a new course for free focusing on digital security for journalists in times of crisis.

entry.title: Food halls are Europe's hottest culinary trendâ€”here's why
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
A culinary revolution is simmering in Europe. Despite the challenges of a global pandemic, the past eight years have seen the number of food halls across the continent double, completely reshaping the dining scene. Traditionally associated with the hawker centres of Southeast Asia, the trend of multiple vendors and a variety of cuisines under one roof has now reached more than 135 locations with more sites being sought every week.
For the vendor, food halls provide a platform to showcase their talent without the risks associated with opening a restaurant; for the consumer, a plethora of options at a more affordable price point. Authenticity, locality and sustainability are key factors for many potential visitors, â€¦

entry.title: DR Congo: New initiative to eliminate HIV in children â€˜a beacon of hopeâ€™
entry.summary: The Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) has launched a bold new national initiative aimed at eliminating AIDS among children by 2030 â€“ a move hailed by the United Nations as â€œa beacon of hopeâ€ amid growing global funding constraints.

entry.title: Everything you need to know about Scottish whisky
entry.summary:
In Scotland, whiskey is produced in every corner of the country, and there are complex contrasts between them, from an eye-opening Islay whisky, a sweet sip from Speyside or the lighter lowland styles. Donâ€™t like whisky? Then you havenâ€™t properly explored Scotch. Scotlandâ€™s whisky-makers are masters of malts, offering more flavour variety, production prowess and heritage than anywhere else in the world. Hereâ€™s our ultimate guide, with Scottish drams to delight every drinker.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
These days, every nation is discovering whisky distillation, but the global superstars are without doubt the Scottish. With a production history dating back to the 15th century, the country has spent hundreds of years perfecting distillatiâ€¦

entry.title: Beyond the beach, Antalya makes for a cultural city break
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Gateway to the Turkish Riviera, Antalya basks in the sunshine on the countryâ€™s southern Mediterranean coast, hugging the gulf that bears its name. Modern but with a picturesque, ancient heart, the city centres around a Roman-era harbour and the lattice of cobblestone lanes that make up the old town KaleiÃ§i (meaning â€˜within the castleâ€™), which is dotted with centuries-old mosques and restored Ottoman houses. Itâ€™s here that locals pause for long mezze lunches beneath waves of fuschia bougainvillea, or sit with an ice cream to soak up the sight of the Taurus Mountains rising in the distance beyond the bay.
Much like Rome, this is a city that wears its history on its sleeve, with stretches of two-thousand-year-old wallâ€¦

entry.title: LIVE: World leaders in Sevilla launch ambitious push to finance the future
entry.summary: From rising debt and shrinking investment, to the aid funding crisis and struggles to meet ambitious development goals, the global financial system is failing the people it's supposed to serve: that's the challenge facing world leaders gathered in Spain's sweltering southern jewel of Sevilla this week, as the Â UN's 4th International Conference on Financing for Development gets underway. Follow our live Meetings Coverage below; app users can catch all the action from the opening day here and you'll find all related stories on our special dedicated page right here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Faith in finance: Indonesia's innovative path to sustainable development
entry.summary: Indonesia has been putting its faith in innovative approaches to financing to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), the internationally agreed targets to end poverty, hunger and inequality, fight climate change and preserve the planet.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Tide of change in Philippines as women revive watersheds and livelihoods
entry.summary: In the coastal town of Sasmuan, Philippines, life flows with the riverâ€™s tide. At dawn, slender boats glide through calm waters as fishing nets are cast beneath the warming sky.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres welcomes peace deal between DR Congo and Rwanda
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres has welcomed the peace agreement between the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and Rwanda signed on Friday in the United States capital, Washington, DC.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Global solidarity benefits us allâ€™: Spain makes the case for development funding
entry.summary: Funding cuts to international development have cast a pall over a major UN-led international conference set to address the huge challenges faced by countries in the Global South. Despite this sobering backdrop, Eva Granados, Spanish Secretary of State for International Cooperation, insists that global solidarity is still alive, despite indications to the contrary.

entry.title: Was Alexander the Great really poisoned?
entry.summary:
The sick Alexander (Alessandro infermo), by Domenico Induno, 19th Century, oil on canvas. Alexander drinks from a cup to show his trust in the doctor who gave it to him and condemns Parmenione who told him he would be poisoned. This event was said to take place in 333 B.C., 10 years prior to Alexander's death. The young conqueror fell suddenly and fatally ill at an all-night feast. Now, a Stanford historian has found a potential culprit.
In June 323 BCE, in the palace of King Nebuchadnezzar II in Babylon, the most powerful man in the world died. Just 13 days earlier, Alexander the Greatâ€”the greatest conqueror the world had seenâ€”had been drinking at one of his many all-night banquets when he suddenly cried out in pain. He was sent to bed suffering from abdominal pain and a fever, anâ€¦

entry.title: These treasures changed what we thought about the Celts
entry.summary:
During the Iron Age (circa 1200-500 B.C.), a large swath of non-Mediterranean Europe was occupied by a people who became known for their craftsmanship, religion, and warfare. Different groups, now known collectively as Celts, spoke languages belonging to the Celtic family and shared a common ideological framework reflected in a series of divinities they worshipped in religious festivities.
The Romans built up a stereotype of the Celts and other enemies, like the Germanic peoples, as barbarians. They caricatured them as blond, white-skinned giants from the north with a primitive tendency for drunkenness and violence. This clicheÌ helped condition how researchers regarded the Celts. But in recent decades, new readings of the classical sources and some fascinating archaeological discoverâ€¦

entry.title: Take a mouthwatering trip down Alabamaâ€™s Barbecue Trail
entry.summary:
Texas has brisket, Memphis has ribs. The Carolinas enjoy their pulled pork, and Kansas City is all about the sauce game. But not many immediately associate barbecue with Alabama. Well, except for one thingâ€”the mayonnaise-y white sauce.
While the stateâ€™s polarizing contribution to the American barbecue consciousness celebrates its 100th anniversary this year, thereâ€™s much more to the stateâ€™s barbecue than white sauce, and many Alabamians would proudly put their barbecue among the best in the country. With a mouthwatering Alabama Barbecue Trailâ€”from civil rights hot spots to 100-year-old jointsâ€”thereâ€™s no better way to uncover Alabamaâ€™s unique cuisine and history than biting into it.
Barbecue borrows the cooking methods of Native Americans, meats and sauces of European immigrantsâ€¦

entry.title: What is colonialism?
entry.summary:
Christopher Columbus set sail from Spain in 1492. In recent years, the story of this journey has evolved from an exciting tale of exploration to an event marking the beginning of violence against Indigenous populations in North and South America. Colonizing Indigenous peopleâ€”and exploiting their land and resourcesâ€”has a long and brutal history.
Merriam-Webster defines colonialism as â€œcontrol by one power over a dependent area or people.â€ It occurs when one nation takes control of another for benefits such as resources. Often, they force their language and culture on the locals.
By 1914, Europeans had colonized a large majority of the worldâ€™s nations at some point. Japan, Korea, and Thailand are the only other nations Europeans never colonized.
Colonialism is closely relatâ€¦

entry.title: When climbing Mount Everest, what counts as cheating?
entry.summary:
In 1978, Austrian physician and mountaineer Oswald Oelz was a team doctor on an expedition to Mount Everest when climbers Reinhold Messner and Peter Habeler became the first people to reach its summit without supplemental oxygen. Before then, it was unthinkable that humans, unassisted, could climb 29,032 feet, the height of Everest, where due to drop in atmospheric pressure we inhale only about 30 percent of the oxygen we breath at sea level.
Almost half a century later, Oelzâ€™s grand-nephew, Austrian climbing guide Lukas Furtenbach, was the architect of a new feat atop Mount Everest. This May, four of his clients, along with five Sherpas, summited the worldâ€™s tallest mountain only five days after they left London. Usually, it takes an average of 40 days of slow acclimatisation to adjuâ€¦

entry.title: A Swiss village was buried under a mountain. This town could be next.
entry.summary:
In this aerial view, rubble and ice fill a portion of the Loetschental Valley following a landslide on June 3, 2025 in Blatten, Switzerland. Over 317 million cubic feet of rubble, mud, and ice fell on to Blatten on May 28. In the past century, scientists have observed more rockfalls and avalanches in the Alps, a looming threat to nearby villages.
Last month, Lukas Kalbermatten-Ritler stood in a hamlet overlooking the small Swiss village of Blatten opposite the Birch Glacier, holding up his camera phone up in disbelief.
â€œIt was like a bomb went off,â€ says Kalbermatten-Ritler, whoâ€™s home and historic third-generation family-owned Hotel Edelweiss was destroyed on May 28. â€œThere were black rocks coming like a wall over the glacier, like it was a big hand taking the village. Thâ€¦

entry.title: Meet the Colombians shaking up Cartagena's cultural scene
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The roar of scooters battles with the beat of salsa and the bellows of market stallholders. Plantains blanket the ground, and corn-loaded carts criss-cross between people and rogue chickens. AnÂ artist paints posters for the cityâ€™s upcoming festivals while a man sits in a plastic chair on the pavement and gets a haircut. This is Cartagenaâ€™s open-air Bazurto Market, and itâ€™s a labyrinth of unfiltered chaos.
The market, a few miles outside the city centre, is full of Cartageneros like local chef MarÃ­a Cecilia Restrepo, simply known as Chechi, who come here to buy their fish, meat, fruit and vegetables. â€œThe smells, the colours, knowing where our food comes from: it all provides context to the cuisine of Cartagena,â€ shâ€¦

entry.title: Video shows rare fireball meteor explode in broad daylight
entry.summary:
Illustration of a fireball passing in front of the moon as it crosses through Earth's atmosphere. Fireball meteors fall on the Earth every day but it's rare to see one in the daytime. Fireballs fall on the Earth every dayâ€”but the one that just streaked across the southeastern U.S. this week was unlike the rest. Hereâ€™s why.
People across Georgia on Thursday witnessed an unusual flash of light streaking through the bright blue sky, followed by a thunderous boom that rattled windows. But there were no thunderstorms in the area. The culprit? An exceptionally bright meteor called a fireball.
Videos from dashcams and security cameras shared online caught the event, which occurred around 12:24 p.m. EDT on June 26. It was also observed by a lightning detector on the National Oceanic aâ€¦

entry.title: Syria: UN commission hails recent action to address past violations
entry.summary: The interim authorities in Syria have taken important steps in recent weeks to address past violations, the Chair of the Independent International Commission of Inquiry on the country said on Friday in an update to Â the UN Human Rights Council in Geneva.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Lacroix upholds role of UN peacekeeping in Lebanon and Syria
entry.summary: The head of UN Peacekeeping affirmed the critical role played by the â€œblue helmetsâ€ in Lebanon and Syria during a press conference at Headquarters in New York.

entry.title: DR Congo: Despite efforts towards a political solution, violence still rages in the east
entry.summary: As the Foreign Ministers of Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) signed a draft peace agreement in Washington this Friday, tensions and violence continue to grip eastern DRC.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: New UN report charts path out of debt crisis threatening global development
entry.summary: A decade after the adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), development is facing serious headwinds â€“ including what UN officials describe as a â€œsilent crisisâ€ of surging debt service payments in low-income countries.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan: â€˜Fighting shows no signs of abating,â€™ senior UN official tells Security Council
entry.summary: Three years into the conflict in Sudan, the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) and Sudan Armed Forces (SAF) continue to pursue a military solution, violating international law and the rights of civilians in the process.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Myanmar human rights crisis deepens as aid collapses, attacks intensify
entry.summary: Myanmar is spiralling deeper into humanitarian catastrophe, the UNâ€™s top human rights official warned on Friday, as escalating military attacks, crippling aid restrictions and collapsing international support push millions toward starvation and despair.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Short-range drone attacks deepen crisis on Ukrainian frontlines
entry.summary: Attacks with short-range drones killed at least 395 civilians and injured 2,635 between February 2022 â€“ the start of Russiaâ€™s full-scale invasion of Ukraine â€“ and April 2025, the UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission (HRMMU) reported on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres calls for immediate Gaza ceasefire as humanitarian crisis reaches â€˜horrific proportionsâ€™
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres on Friday reiterated his call for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza, warning that the humanitarian crisis has reached â€œhorrific proportionsâ€ and that the world must not let the suffering of Palestinians be overshadowed by other regional conflicts.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Health system crumbles amid growing desperation over food, fuel
entry.summary: The first delivery earlier this week of urgently needed medical goods to enter Gaza in months will provide scant relief to the enclaveâ€™s people, who continue to be shot and killed in their search for food, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) said on Friday.

entry.title: 8 stunning sights in the night sky this July
entry.summary:
One of the closest and brightest globular clusters visible from Earth, M22 contains hundreds of thousands of stars packed into a tight, elliptical shape about 10,000 light-years away. Get your binoculars ready for dark skies, elusive planets, and a sky show spanning the entire month.
Stargazers, get ready to take in some awe-inspiring sights. This month offers a parade of star clusters, meteors, and various planet sightings, including the difficult-to-spot dwarf planet Pluto. Hereâ€™s what to look for in the July night sky.
The globular cluster Messier 22 (M22) reaches its highest point in the sky around midnight local time, specifically for observers south of 46Â° N latitude, since M22â€™s position favors the Southern Hemisphere.
Located about 10,000 light-years away in theâ€¦

entry.title: A music loverâ€™s guide to Tokyo
entry.summary:
A Cajun-style band performs on a street in Tokyoâ€™s Koenji neighborhood. Itâ€™s just one of several places to experience the cityâ€™s eclectic music scene. From record stores to jazz cafes to karaoke, here are the best ways to keep up with everything this music-infused city has to offer.
If you're a record collector, a guitar nerd, a jazz head, a garage rocker, or a karaoke crooner, Tokyo is possibly the best place on the planet for music lovers. Before planning a trip to Japan's capital city, here's what you need to know about its diverse music scene for all types of musicophiles.
Ask anyone who has visited Tokyo about record shopping and they will all mentionÂ Disk Union. The behemoth music retailer has been around since 1967 and has multiple stores across the city. In Shinjuku â€¦

entry.title: A roadrunner in your neighborhood? It's a growing possibility.
entry.summary:
About a decade ago, Mary Taylor Young and her husband were pulling into the driveway of their cabin, a property nestled at 6,700 feet, in southern Colorado. Suddenly, they saw a face that they werenâ€™t expecting: a roadrunner, with its signature spiky head crest and baby blue coloring around the eyes.Â
â€œMy husband and I were both like, â€˜Oh, my God, what is a roadrunner doing here?â€™â€ Young, a biologist and nature writer, says. â€œâ€˜Dude, you belong in the desert. What are you doing?â€™â€
Young says it wasnâ€™t unheard of to see roadrunners in and around the nearby town of Trinidad, Colorado, which sits at about 6,000 feet in the northernmost part of the roadrunnerâ€™s range in the state. However, she was surprised by this higher altitude sighting, something thatâ€™s becoming more common.Â â€¦

entry.title: New tech could tell you when it's too dangerous to be outside
entry.summary:
Two people pick grapes in a vineyard near Fresno, California. Outdoor farm workers are on average 35 times more likely to experience heat-related illnesses than the general population. Illnesses caused by heatâ€”dehydration, cramps, and even strokesâ€”can come on quickly and quietly. New, wearable technology could help alert wearers to lurking danger.
After 10 straight hours picking grapes on a scorching 105Â°F day in Bakersfield, California, in 2004 53-year-old AsunciÃ³n Valdivia collapsed and died, a victim of heat stroke.Â Â
Some 436 workers later died from environmental heat exposure between 2011 and 2021 in the United States, and Valdiviaâ€™s death became emblematic of this risk, inspiring a bill introduced in Congress in 2023 to create safer conditions for laborers who work in eâ€¦

entry.title: These 3 cities near Paris deserve more than a day trip
entry.summary:
Chantilly, Fontainebleau, and Versailes are normally tacked on as day trips from Paris, but these three destinations are worth more time. If they werenâ€™t eclipsed by the City of Light, Versailles, Chantilly, and Fontainebleau would be pilgrimages in their own right. Hereâ€™s why theyâ€™re worth an overnight stay.
Paris lures millions of visitors every year, but day trips are a perennially popular diversion. The Chateau of Versailles, mind-blowing in its grandeur, has instant name recognition all over the world. The Chateau of Fontainebleau coddled eight centuriesâ€™ worth of French monarchs, and its forest was where the worldâ€™s first-marked hiking trails were born. And Chantilly, equestrian epicenter renowned for its racetrack, is home to Franceâ€™s most important antique art museum, afterâ€¦

entry.title: In this Italian region, Alpine cultures collide
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Trentino is a province of collisions. Stitched to the forested underbelly of South Tyrol, just south of the Swiss and Austrian borders, its spruce forests and opalescent lakes are shadowed by the Dolomites: grey-pink sharkâ€™s teeth mountains formed when the African and European tectonic plates made impact some 60 million years ago.
For the ancient Romans, these were frontier lands, with the nearby Brenner Pass on the Austrian border serving as a gateway for peoples, languages and recipes from the other side of the Alps. Today, those influences can be felt in everything from the hearty stews served in Trentinoâ€™s timber-framed restaurants to the old German dialect spoken in its remote mountain enclaves.
Though itâ€¦

entry.title: Where to sample Australiaâ€™s best rumâ€”and its rich history
entry.summary:
During the 18th century,Â England sought out remote locations to house prisoners as a solution to its overcrowded jails.Â In 1788, England'sÂ First FleetÂ arrived inÂ the Eora nationâ€”now known as Sydney,Â Australiaâ€”withÂ 11 ships of convictsÂ and officers. For this long voyage, they packed two yearsâ€™ worth of food and four yearsâ€™ worth of rum.Â
The nation was founded without any formal currency exceptÂ a limited supply of coins, because it was meant to be a convict colony. However, it soon became clear they would need more structure, so they put their bountiful supply of rum to practical use.Â
Rum became intertwined with the history of Australia. It was the original currency, the spirit of rebellion, and a powerful political tool.Â
(Take a mangrove foraging tour with Broomeâ€™s Aborigiâ€¦

entry.title: These are the best gin joints in all the world
entry.summary:
Gin distillers around the world offer gin-making classes, lessons, and tastings. From London to Wisconsin, one-day gin academies across the globe let the public brew their own spirits. You might not go home with a diplomaâ€”but you will go home with the worldâ€™s rarest gin.
There's something hypnotic about watching gin transform before your eyes, especially when you've selected every botanical that goes into it. This is the allure of gin academies, where visitors don't just tour facilities and taste spiritsâ€”they sit down to copper stills and shelves of botanicals, creating a bottle of gin themselves,
Typically one-day workshops, enthusiasts become distillers for a day. From London to Wisconsin, hereâ€™s where gin lovers can roll up their sleeves and try the ancient alchemy of distiâ€¦

entry.title: Faith Kipyegon falls short in attempt to break 4-minute mile
entry.summary:
Faith Kipyegon approaches the finish line in her attempt to become the first woman to run a mile in under four minutes. The Kenyan beat the current world record, but missed out on the mythic barrier by six seconds.
Faith Kipyegon ran the mile of her life today. And yet the 31-year-old Kenyan, the best female middle-distance runner of all time, failed to add a new line to the history books, by running six seconds shy of becoming the first woman to run one mile in under four minutes.
Surrounded by pacers, Kipyegon streaked around the track at Parisâ€™ Stade SÃ©bastien CharlÃ©ty in a time of 4:06.42. The blistering run was more than a second faster than the world record that she already owns. Still, the result meant that history would have to wait for another day.Â
To break fouâ€¦

entry.title: Hereâ€™s why you should visit Vail in the summertime
entry.summary:
Summertime in Vail brings ideal weather for outdoor fun, from hiking and to river tubing and browsing farmers markets. Coloradoâ€™s largest ski resort has a lot to offer in the warmer months, including scenic gondola rides, music festivals, world-class art, and backcountry hiking trailsâ€”without the crowds.
Snow-dusted peaks flanking the Bavarian-style villages, perfect for a day of skiing. Ice skating in the heart of the squares. Cozy cafes and bars from which to enjoy a hot chocolate or hot toddy. These are likely the winter wonderland images that come to mind when you think of Vail. But, after the ski season winds down and the temperatures start to increase, this Colorado resort area makes a greatâ€”and less crowdedâ€”place for a summer travel adventure.
Surrounded by the Rocky Moâ€¦

entry.title: The most otherworldly, mysterious forms of lightning on Earth
entry.summary:
Our atmosphere is like one big electrical circuit: Thunderstorms are the batteries that charge it up, and lightning is the current flowing through it. On the ground we see evidence of this circuit when lightning cracks and strikes the ground, or when it lights up deep inside a thundercloud, but high above the clouds lies a secret electrical zoo full of sprites, elves, and jets.Â
These fantastical terms refer to light displays called transient luminous events or TLEs that occur in Earthâ€™s upper atmosphere during thunderstorms. â€œTLEs are mysterious, beautiful, and uniquely different from conventional lightning, yet they connect weather, space, and electricity in one dramatic moment. They occur high above the clouds, almost silently, and are invisible to most peopleâ€”but they reflect poweâ€¦

entry.title: This creature can 3D-print its own body parts
entry.summary:
The larvae of a bristle worm, saltwater worms with elaborate, hair-like structures. Bristle worms have protrusions that act like a 3D printer, helping us to understand how cells regenerate.
  Most people will never see a bristle worm in the wild, but according to a new study, the science derived from these bristly beasts may someday benefit you or someone you know.Â  Bristle wormsâ€”aka polychaetesâ€” are saltwater worms with elaborate, hair-like structures; in some species, they allow the animals to paddle through the open ocean or â€œwalkâ€ across the seafloor.Â  â€œOne of the reasons that weâ€™re interested in bristle worms is because theyâ€™re great models for regeneration biology,â€ saysÂ Florian Raible, a molecular biologist at the University of Vienna in Austria. â€œSo, they â€¦

entry.title: What your noisy knees are trying to tell you
entry.summary:
Joint sounds like cracking and popping are often harmlessâ€”but when paired with pain or stiffness, they may signal early arthritis. Experts say age isnâ€™t the only factorâ€”diet, inflammation, and movement play a big role in how your joints hold up over time. From gas bubbles to worn cartilage, hereâ€™s what makes your joints popâ€”and how to know if itâ€™s something to worry about.
Snap. Crackle. Pop. If your knees sound like a bowl of cereal every time you stand, youâ€™re not alone.
â€œThose cracking or popping sounds people hear are really common. We call it â€˜crepitusâ€™ in the medical world and, most of the time, itâ€™s just a normal part of joint mechanics,â€ says Mitchell McDowell, an orthopedic surgeon, osteopathic physician, and president of M Bone and Joint. â€œIt could be tiny gas bubbleâ€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: Pew Research Center conducted this study to understand how Americans voted in 2024 and how their turnout and vote choices differed from 2016 and 2020. For this analysis, we surveyed 8,942 U.S. citizens ages 18 and older who are members of the Centerâ€™s American Trends Panel (ATP). We verified their turnout in the five general [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals: Research team Jocelyn Kiley, Director, Political ResearchScott Keeter, Senior Survey AdvisorHannah Hartig, Senior ResearcherBaxter Oliphant, Senior ResearcherGabe Borelli, Research AssociateAndrew Daniller, Research AssociateAndy Cerda, Research AnalystJoseph Copeland, Research AnalystTed Van Green, Research AnalystShanay Gracia, Research Assistant Communications and editorial [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Demographic profiles of Trump and Harris voters in 2024
entry.summary: The composition of Republican and Democratic voters in the United States has changed since the 2020 presidential election, and the shifts have been even larger since the 2016 contest. Donald Trumpâ€™s voters overall were more racially and ethnically diverse in 2024 than in his prior campaigns, reflecting gains among Hispanic, Black and Asian voters. Conversely, [â€¦] The post 3. Demographic profiles of Trump and Harris voters in 2024 appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Voting patterns in the 2024 election
entry.summary: For the most part, voting patterns across demographic groups in the 2024 presidential election were not substantially different from the 2020 and 2016 elections. But Donald Trumpâ€™s gains among several key groups of voters proved decisive in his 2024 victory. To explore voting patterns among subgroups over time, refer to detailed tables. Hispanic voters were [â€¦] The post 2. Voting patterns in the 2024 election appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Voter turnout, 2020-2024
entry.summary: Because partisanship and voting preference are highly correlated â€“ and most adults stick with their preferred party over time â€“ voter turnout is often a key factor in understanding why there are changes in electoral outcomes year to year. In the 2024 presidential election, a higher share of Donald Trumpâ€™s 2020 voters than Joe Bidenâ€™s [â€¦] The post 1. Voter turnout, 2020-2024 appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Behind Trumpâ€™s 2024 Victory, a More Racially and Ethnically Diverse Voter Coalition
entry.summary: Pew Research Centerâ€™s in-depth study of its survey respondents who voted in the 2024 election examines turnout, voting patterns and demographics. The post Behind Trumpâ€™s 2024 Victory, a More Racially and Ethnically Diverse Voter Coalition appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Millions remain invisible â€“ but Asia-Pacific leaders pledge change by 2030
entry.summary: More than a decade after Asian and Pacific nations launched a campaign to ensure every life is counted, millions across the region still remain â€œinvisibleâ€ â€“ born, living, and dying without formal recognition.

entry.title: Upcoming elections â€˜crucial opportunityâ€™ for Central African Republic, UN top official tells Security Council
entry.summary: As the Central African Republic (CAR) prepares for upcoming elections, the country continues to grapple with a fragile security and humanitarian context, the UN Security Council heard on Thursday.

entry.title: Ukraine: Increasing hostilities displace civilians, limit humanitarian access
entry.summary: Deadly hostilities continued along the front-line regions of Ukraine on Wednesday, displacing civilians and damaging civilian infrastructure, the UN has reported.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo: Conflictâ€™s survivors have been through hell, says UN aid chief
entry.summary: The conflict-impacted people of the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) urgently need much more international assistance than they are getting today, the UNâ€™s top aid official said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.summary: It wasnâ€™t an average Thursday morning in Manhattan. In the early hours, UN diplomats (and UN News) hit the streets in their sneakers â€“ from Times Square to East River â€“ following a route that traced the shape of â€œUN@80â€.

entry.title: UN calls for restraint after deadly Kenya protests
entry.summary: The UN is monitoring the situation in Kenya in the wake of deadly antigovernment protests on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rights office sounds the alarm over forced displacement in the West Bank
entry.summary: Palestinians in the occupied West Bank, including East Jerusalem, are increasingly being subjected to forced displacement and land seizures, the UN human rights office, OHCHR, has reported.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Our kids cry for foodâ€™: Most families in Gaza survive on one meal a day
entry.summary: Most families in the Gaza Strip are surviving on one meal a day and one-third go entire days without eating as a result of Israelâ€™s continued bombardment of the enclave, according to the UN World Food Programme (WFP) and partners.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Despite the fall of Assad, the illicit drug trade in Syria is far from over
entry.summary: When Bashar Al-Assad ruled Syria, his regime was widely accused of profiting from the production and trafficking of Captagon, an illicit synthetic drug that is most commonly abused by users in the Middle East.

entry.title: Video: How do American men and women differ religiously?
entry.summary: The gender gap in American religion is shrinking. Historically, women have been more religious than men. But the gap is smaller than it once was. The post Video: How do American men and women differ religiously? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Spirituality and Religion: How Does the U.S. Compare With Other Countries?
entry.summary: Explore how adults in the U.S. and 35 other countries compare religiously and spiritually when it comes to affiliation, prayer, afterlife beliefs and more. The post Spirituality and Religion: How Does the U.S. Compare With Other Countries? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: How to plan a trip to see Africa's Great Migration
entry.summary:
Africaâ€™s Great Migration is a world-renowned wildlife phenomenon where more than a million wildebeest, along with countless zebras and gazelles, follow the rains across Tanzaniaâ€™s Serengeti and Kenyaâ€™s Maasai Mara in a relentless quest for greener pastures. Each year, Africaâ€™s Great Migration sees millions of wildebeest and zebra thunder across the sun-bleached savannah, drawn by instinct to cross crocodile-infested rivers where predators lie in wait. But beyond the chaos, this epic journey reveals a deeper, more complex tale of survival and symbiosis on the Serengeti stage.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
To a soundtrack of thundering hooves and panicked brays, wildebeest plunge into the muddy Mara River, churning the water as sly crocodilesâ€¦

entry.title: The small Swiss town where people still vote by hands in the air
entry.summary:
For most of the year, big crowds are unusual in the Swiss town of Glarus. At the base of a dramatic point in the Alps called the GlÃ¤rnisch ridge, the hamlet is tranquil, largely undisturbed by the tourists who descend on the regionâ€™s picturesque areas. But every year there is one dayâ€”usually the first Sunday in Mayâ€”where citizens of the canton gather en masse in the town square for a tradition thatâ€™s over 700 years old. Questions are boomed over the loudspeakers and thousands of people raise their hands in response. This is the Landsgemeindeâ€”one of the world's oldest forms of direct democracy still in practice.Â Â
Meaning â€œcantonal community assemblyâ€ in German, the Landsgemeinde dates back to medieval times. Glarus, with its population of around 41,000 people, is one of only two Swissâ€¦

entry.title: Why Romeâ€™s dolphins are fighting each other
entry.summary:
Rome, the Eternal City, is revered for its history, art, culture, and food. Yet, few people know that less thanÂ an hour away, where the Tiber River flows into the Tyrrhenian Sea, thereâ€™s something that makes the area even more unique: a population of around 500 bottlenose dolphins.Â
Now, aÂ recent studyÂ shows that the dolphins are not only sick, but theyâ€™re fighting over foodâ€”and itâ€™s due to human activity.Â
The â€œCapitoline dolphins,â€ as researchers have named them, have inhabited the coast outside Rome for thousands of years, as shown by mosaics from the archaeological site of Ostia Antica that depict the dolphins stealing fish from fishermen's nets 2,000 years ago. Yet theyâ€™ve only recently been closely studied, beginning in 2016.Â Two male dolphins have an aggressive encoâ€¦

entry.title: Why this photographer made a camera lens out of glacial ice
entry.summary:
Artist Tristan Duke traveled to Svalbard, Norway, in 2022 to create camera lenses made from shards of pristine ice pulled from glacial waters. Tristan Duke uses Arctic ice and a unique technique to offer a fresh perspective on a world transformed by climate change.
Glacial ice is formed fromÂ snow accumulating and compacting over millennia. As the pressure increases, crystalline layers are smoothed into one of the clearest substances found in nature. That alchemyâ€”and the knowledge that climate change is causing glaciers to rapidly disappearâ€”inspired 44-year-old artist Tristan Duke to create a photo lens out of glacial ice. â€œI just felt this real sense of urgency,â€ Duke says. He wanted to capture a glacier through its own â€œeye,â€ as he puts it, like a self-portrait.
In the spring of 2022, Duke hauled hundreds of pounds of gear to Svalbard, Norway, including a giant tent camera that he designed himself and molds for shaping the ice into lenses. The tent functioned like a camera obscura: Duke would place a palm-size piece of ice in a hole in the canvas, projecting an image of the landscape inside the tent that would then be captured on a 42-by-100-inch negative.
Some of the photographs were clearer than he expected, but as the lenses melted, the accumulation of water produced its own effect. â€œPeople have told me that it looks like the world blurred through tears,â€ he says.
To contrast this Arctic sublime against a world on fire, he traveled through the American West to document wildfires and energy infrastructure with lenses created from locally sourced ice. He wants to invert the romantic gaze. â€œWe see a sort of fragile nature bearing witness to the unbridled and cataclysmic power of the human world.â€ undefined undefined A version of this story appears in the July 2025 issueÂ ofÂ National GeographicÂ magazine.

entry.title: Britainâ€™s first Black queen? The real story of Queen Charlotte
entry.summary:
When 17-year-old Sophia Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz caught her first glimpse of the London palace that was to be her home in 1761, she turned pale. She was set to become Queen of Great Britain and Ireland within hours, but she had never set foot in England or met her husband-to-be.
What happened next is the stuff of royal history, brought to recent light in Netflixâ€™s limited series, Queen Charlotte: a Bridgerton Story fictionalizing the life of the timid German girl rumored to have been Britainâ€™s first Black queen. But who was the real Queen Charlotte?
Born in 1744 in Mecklenburg-Strelitz, a duchy in what is now northern Germany, the princess had an unremarkable childhood in what other members of the European aristocracy considered to be a mediocre and provincial dukedom.â€¦

entry.title: Try a detour on your next trip to these classic destinations
entry.summary:
Philadelphia's Magic Gardens is an art gallery meets community center on South Street. Detour destinations, aka lesser-known spots, are trending in travel for several reasons. Try one of these getaways that are less crowded and offer rich local experiences.
A recent Expedia travel trends report shows that, remarkably, 63 percent of travelers plan to include lesser-known spots in their travels this year, with destinations that offer locally rich experiences.
A detour destination doesnâ€™t mean completely avoiding a popular destination. It can also involve a night or two in that tried-and-true destination, just with an alternate destination also worked into the plans, for reasons including lower costs and new experiences.
Just 15 minutes from busy Monterey, Carmel-by-thâ€¦

entry.title: Visiting Istanbul? Hereâ€™s where to eat
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Thereâ€™s no shortage of good reasons to visit Istanbul â€” from its flagship attractions such as the Hagia Sophia and the Basilica Cistern to the seductive rhythms of its busier neighbourhoods and the tranquillity of its islands. Yet its standout feature is arguably its cuisine. This is a city thatâ€™s been home to an impressive, bustling dining scene for over two millennia â€” and, while many travellers limit themselves to the prix fixe menus in the Historical Peninsula, thereâ€™s a greater culinary depth available to those willing to venture beyond the touristy kebab shops. Here are nine of the cityâ€™s best dining options â€” restaurants that excite the locals and offer visitors something theyâ€™re unlikely to forget. Â
â€¦

entry.title: How to lower stress in 5 minutes
entry.summary:
Feeling overwhelmed? Youâ€™re not alone. Between meetings, errands, and the endless scroll of everyday life, stress builds up fastâ€”and it doesnâ€™t just take a toll on your mood. It can disrupt your sleep, spike your heart rate, and weaken your immune system.
But hereâ€™s the good news: research shows that even small, low-effort actions can help your body reset. Here are six things you can do right nowâ€”and the science behind why they work.
Few things affect your nervous system as immediatelyâ€”or as powerfullyâ€”as your breath. Studies show that deep breathing can lower blood pressure, slow your heart rate, and boost heart rate variabilityâ€”a key marker of resilience. It also reduces cortisol, the stress hormone associated with a range of issues, including poor sleep and brain fog. Controâ€¦

entry.title: An LED track, super shoes, and a suit made from Aeronodes
entry.summary:
7.65 seconds.Â
Thatâ€™s the amount of time that Kenyan Faith Kipyegon needs to shave from her world record time in order to become the first woman to run the mile in under 4 minutes.Â Â
Kipyegon, a three-time gold medalist, has spent months training for an exhibition on Thursday in Paris where sheâ€™ll take a crack at the mythic sub-four barrier. An attempt, she says, to â€œcement her legacy.â€Â Â Â
The event, dubbed Breaking4, is being staged by Nike, Kipyegon's sponsor. To help her make history, everyone from physiologists to shoe designers have rallied to find ways to help her trim every hundredth of a second possibleâ€”some of which make the run ineligible for official world records.Â Â
Itâ€™s a tricky task. The mile is short enough that small benefits have little time to accrete â€¦

entry.title: Dine like in The Bear at these Chicago fine dining spots
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
From beef sandwiches to Michelin-star-seeking menus â€” TV show The Bearâ€™s fictional restaurant has given us a story arc that, in many ways, mirrors the real-life culinary history of the city itâ€™s set in. Just as the Original Beef of Chicagoland was transformed from a sauce-splattered sandwich bar into the showâ€™s titular fine-dining venture, so too has Chicago evolved from a meatpacking capital to one of Americaâ€™s pioneering food cities.
One upon a time, fine dining in the Windy City mostly consisted of steak and potatoes. Then in 1987, Charlie Trotter opened his eponymous restaurant in Lincoln Park. Using French and Japanese techniques and lots of fresh vegetables, Trotter â€” like The Bearâ€™s chef, Carmy â€” was determiâ€¦
